Translation: An eye for an eye and tooth for a tooth

Dagaare: vɛŋ ka fo gaa mɛɛle ayi ne o
ka o de koɔ a neba niŋe eŋe a pɛge o nuuri
Translation: Wash your hands of the matter

Dagaare: Ta ko bare boŋ naŋ e bonsoŋ, bee lɔɔ yɛ lɛpɛl-veɛlaa eŋ dobaare poɔ
A soba na zaa naŋ ba taa yelbieri a yɛpoɔ, yɛ vɛŋ ka o de weɛ de kuurii za neŋ a pɔgo
Translation: To cast the first stone/People who live in glass houses must not throw stones
In/By the twinkling of an eye

Dagaare: yɛ le la yi a nɔndeteroo sobiri poɔ
Translation: To fall from grace to grass

Dagaare: ta le a nakuoraa na noɔre naŋ nɛbrɛ a bombie
Translation: Do not muzzle out the ox that treads the grain

Dagaare: Ka zɔŋ wa tagra zɔŋ, ba zaa bayi na laŋ le la a bɔg poɔ
Translation: If the blind lead the blind, both will fall in a pit

Dagaare: Yiri na zaa naŋ poŋ kyaare ne o meŋɛ koŋ toɔ are
Translation: No city or house divided against itself will stand

Dagaare: Balaŋ naŋ voɔ a soɔ na bɔre wɛ la a soɔ eŋɛ
Translation: All who take the sword will perish by the sword

Dagaare: A kuuri na mɛmeɛrebɛ naŋ zagre, waa la a goŋgonaa zukuuri
Translation: The stone that the builders rejected, has become the cornerstone

Dagaare: Kyɛ a sobiri naŋ gɛrɛ a Nyɔvore zie ne a be dendɔree la bile
Neɛ bamaŋ de pɛmpaala a liiri ne kparekora
Translation: No man seweth a piece of new cloth on an old garment
Breathed His last/He gave up the ghost

Dagaare: Yiri kaŋa zaa naŋ poŋ kyaare ne o meŋɛ na le la

Translation: A cross you have to bear

Dagaare: Kaara lɛ nensaala naŋ waa kyɛ dire o sarɛɛ
A soba na naŋ ba taa yelbieri zaa a yɛ poɔ, yɛ vɛŋ ka o de weɛ de kuurii za
Ye le la yi a nɔndeteroo sobiri poɔ
Bon na neɛ naŋ bore, onɔ la ka o na kyɛ
Translation: Whatever one sows, that will he reap

Dagaare: Bonso libie nɔmmo la a yelfaa eroŋ yaga piilu zie
Translation: The love of money is a root of all kinds of evil

Dagaare: Kŏɔnoɔ ane kŏɔtuo natŏɔ bullo yire la ziyenaa bee?…Can a fig tree bear olives, or a grapevine produce figs?
Translation: Does a spring pour forth from the same opening both fresh and salt water?…Can a fig tree bear olives, or a grapevine produce figs?

Dagaare: Baa maŋ leɛ di la o meŋɛ tiiri
Translation: The dog returns to his own vomit

Translation: An Eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth.

Translation: A cross you have to bear

Dagaare: Kaara lɛ nensaala naŋ waa kyɛ dire o sarɛɛ
A soba na naŋ ba taa yelbieri zaa a yɛ poɔ, yɛ vɛŋ ka o de weɛ de kuurii za...
Ye le la yi a nɔndeteroo sobiri poɔ

Translation: The love of money is the root of all evil.

Translation: Does a fountain send forth at the same place sweet water and bitter…Can a fig tree bear olive berries?
Sour water, mostly used in preparing T.Z
A male child born on the day pito has been brewed in the house
Funeral where the corpse isn’t buried yet
Early part of mourning at a funeral
A woman who has just given birth
Yes, the sun has reached me

Dagaare: N kͻ́ͻ́ré là fó nyááó fò yiri bé lá sóng?
Translation: Where are you going to? Are you traveling?

Dagaare: Yèng lá ká fó wà tàllà gέrέ?
N gέrέ lá ká ń kpáárè kpòló
Yéng lá ká fó yí wààná?
Ánkáráá lá ká ñ yí wààná
Yèng lá ká fó dé́ὲ wà tàllà gborͻ̀gborͻ̀ lέ gέrέ?
Ǹ wà gέrέ ka N de lͻ̀ͻ̀rè àgàà Wà
Translation: I am on my way to catch a bus for Wa.

Dagaare: Fò ná kyéng sóng. Kyέ fó tͻ̀ͻ̀ wà kͻ̀ͻ̀rͻ̀
Translation: Safe journey. But please do not keep long.

Dagaare: Tόὸ, bárká, kyέ Ǹ kòng kͻ̀ͻ̀ré. Tέέè léé kàngá lá ká N gὲrέká Ñ tè è
Translation: O.k. thanks, I will not keep long. I am only going to sit for a ‘small exam’ {In some cases Dagaaba play down on the exigency of the situation}

Dagaare: wólóngwólóng lá, kà yɛ̀ mèng béɛ́róó?
Translation: It is indeed difficult, and follow-up?

Dagaare: À béé sóng. Kyɛ́ ká fò nyɔ́gé fó mèngɛ́: à wáá túó kyɛ́ tè bá sò á fángá.
Translation: It is fine. But pull yourself together: it is bitter but it is beyond us.

Dagaare: Áyór, ká à bá vòbá bé sóng?
Translation: (upon returning from a funeral), how are the living?

Dagaare: N dɔ́ɔ́ Zìémá, nè fò gɔ́mbéráá wɛ́?
Translation: My friend Ziema, how be the sleeplessness?

Dagaare: Hmm, gɔ́mbéráá là. Ká á yìdèmé bé sóng?
Translation: It’s indeed sleeplessness. How is the family?

Dagaare: Bá béé sóng. Ngmén ná pààlè fò lààféɛ́.
Translation: They are fine. May God grant you healing.

Dagaare: Zúnúò là, n yɔ́ɔ́. Kà á bíírí wááɛ̀ mááróng?
Translation: It’s indeed a fortune. How’re the children?

Dagaare: Bà wááɛ̀ mááróng. Kà á bíé bàà sóng á wá fáá té.
Translation: They’re fine. May the child grow well and save us.
Oo, a ghost or a human?
I should rather be asking you so or?

Dagaare: Sáng lá. Fò mɔ̀ɔ̀ àgé yí là à té Gááná ngá póɔ́ béé?
Translation: It’s really been long. Have you flown outside this our Ghana?

Dagaare: Yèng páng! Té zà̀a bè á kyɛ́ òò n dɔ́ɔ́.
Translation: For where! We are all here oo my friend.

Dagaare: Ká lɛ̀ fò sèrèng bàng là kpéɛ̀bó.
Translation: Then, you have mastered how to stay here.

Dagaare: Àná bérááyí bà séɛ̀ lɔ́gɔ́ yíèé?
Translation: Well os being missed not better than being fed up with?

Dagaare: Ànèng séɛ̀ éng. (Lá ká à dó (lkd) )
Translation: That’s better really better. (Laugh out loud (lol) )

Dagaare: Tè máng gáá lá tómá bàgùó gbèlláàyͻ̀pòí pàr mítì lìzárè né píè
Translation: We go to work at 7.30 a.m.

Dagaare: Tè máng írí lá tómá zù Zìmáánè gbèlláánáárè ngmàà mítì píé
Translation: We close from work at 10 minutes to 4 p.m.

Dagaare: À ngmέ lá gbèlláánáárè pàr mítì píé
Kà ánáng wà ngmὲ gbèláànúú ngmàà mítì píé né ànúú séng má
Translation: When it is quarter to five, wake me up.

The wind is blowing /it is windy
typical Dagaare staple food made of (millet) flour

Translation: Don't get near me is better than leave my hand. (ENG: Prevention is better than cure.)

Dagaare: tágè ka ń tágè lá kyèὲ-né ngmáné
Translation: If we fight over a useful thing we may both lose it.
